question: Question_03_(c)
statement:
\textbf{Short-Answer Question. Simplify your answer as much as possible
and show your work.}

Let $\displaystyle f(x) = \begin{cases}
cx^2 + 3 & \text{if } x \geq 1 \\
2x^3 - c & \text{if } x < 1
\end{cases}$

where \emph{c} is a constant. For what value of the constant \emph{c} is
the function \emph{$f$(x)} continuous on
$\displaystyle (-\infty, \infty)$?
sols:
We are concerned with the continuity of $f$ only at $x=1$, though we
need not be concerned about whether $f(1)$ is defined or not, since its
polynomial 'pieces' are defined on $(-\infty, \infty)$. It remains to
find a $c$ such that
$\lim_{x \to 1} f(x) = \lim_{x \to 1^-} f(x) = \lim_{x \to 1^+} f(x) = f(1)$.

\begin{itemize}
\itemsep1pt\parskip0pt\parsep0pt
\item
  By the definition of $\displaystyle f(x)$ we have
  $f(1) = \lim_{x \to 1^+} f(x) = \lim_{x \to 1^+} cx^2 + 3 = c+3$.
\item
  Furthermore,
  $\lim_{x \to 1^-} f(x) = \lim_{x \to 1^-} 2x^3 - c = 2-c$.
\end{itemize}

Hence we need to find a $\displaystyle c$ such that
$\displaystyle 2 - c = c + 3$. It follows that the value
$\displaystyle c$ that makes $\displaystyle f(x)$ continuous on
$(-\infty, \infty)$ is $c = {\color{blue}\frac{-1}{2}}$.
hints:
What is the definition of continuity? At what $x$-value need we
concerned about the continuity of $f$?

A function is continuous at $\displaystyle a$ if
$\lim_{x \to a} f(x) = f(a)$.
